L1.brief_rationale: The foundational concept of rules governing language structure; universally recognized term at the beginning of any language education.
The primary unit of syntactic analysis; every language learner intuitively understands what a sentence is.
One of the most basic parts of speech, taught in elementary school grammar as words denoting people, places, and things.
Core part of speech denoting actions or states; essential for forming any predicate and taught at the earliest stages of grammar instruction.
Part of speech that modifies nouns; universally taught alongside nouns and verbs in introductory grammar.
Part of speech that modifies verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs; a standard component of basic grammar curricula.
The grammatical role indicating who or what performs the action; a foundational concept introduced in early schooling.
The grammatical role of an entity acted upon by the verb; taught alongside subject as a core sentence component.
Words that substitute for nouns; a basic part-of-speech category familiar to all language users.
Function words expressing spatial, temporal, or logical relations; commonly taught in early grammar as linking words.
Words that connect clauses or phrases; familiar from school grammar as words like 'and', 'but', and 'because'.
The sequence of grammatical constituents in a sentence; intuitively understood by all speakers and a key surface feature of any language.
A group of words containing a subject and predicate; introduced in standard grammar education as the building block of sentences.

L2.brief_rationale: The hierarchical organization of words into phrases; a foundational concept for students entering formal linguistics or advanced grammar study.
A phrase with a noun as its head; students learn to identify NPs as the basic unit of nominal syntax.
A phrase with a verb as its head; central to understanding predicate structure in introductory linguistics courses.
A dependent clause embedded within a main clause; taught in secondary school and introductory linguistics as a key clause type.
A clause that modifies a noun; a commonly analyzed construction in both pedagogical and formal grammar.
The smallest meaningful unit of language; introduced early in linguistics curricula at the boundary of morphology and syntax.
The grammatical encoding of time reference; a fundamental inflectional category taught in early linguistics and language learning.
The grammatical expression of how events unfold over time; closely related to tense and introduced in linguistics survey courses.
The correspondence of grammatical features between constituents; studied by students analyzing inflectional morphology and sentence structure.
The marking of noun phrases for their grammatical role; introduced when students study inflected languages or formal grammar.
The grouping of words into hierarchical units; a core analytical concept introduced in introductory syntax courses.
A function word that introduces a complement clause (e.g., 'that', 'whether'); introduced when students learn about embedded clauses.
A grammatical construction where the syntactic subject is the patient of the verb; analyzed in student-level grammar and introductory syntax.

L3.brief_rationale: A schema for phrase structure positing specifier, head, and complement positions; foundational to Government and Binding and subsequent generative frameworks.
A subtheory governing the distribution of anaphors, pronouns, and R-expressions based on c-command and locality; central to syntactic theory courses.
A syntactic operation moving interrogative or relative phrases to a sentence-initial position; a classic case study in transformational syntax.
A structural dominance relation between nodes in a phrase structure tree; essential for defining binding, scope, and movement constraints.
Semantic roles (agent, patient, theme, etc.) assigned by predicates to their arguments; integral to understanding argument structure in generative syntax.
A parameter specifying whether heads precede or follow their complements; a key typological variable within Principles and Parameters theory.
The proposal that subjects originate within VP and move to SpecTP; a significant revision of clause structure within Government and Binding theory.
The analysis of inflection into separate TP and AgrP projections; a stepping-stone toward modern cartographic approaches to clause structure.
The property of languages allowing null subjects licensed by rich verbal morphology; a classic parametric variation studied in introductory syntactic typology.
Restrictions on syntactic movement out of certain domains (islands); foundational to understanding the limits of transformational operations.
The theory governing the interpretation of null subjects (PRO) in infinitival and gerundive complements; a core module of Government and Binding.
A structural relation in which a head licenses or requires features in an adjacent element; central to Government and Binding theory and case assignment.

L4.brief_rationale: Chomsky's framework reducing syntax to two operations (Merge and Move) driven by interface conditions; the dominant paradigm in contemporary generative syntax.
The proposal that derivations proceed cyclically through phases (vP and CP), with the Phase Impenetrability Condition restricting extraction; a core tenet of Minimalism.
The mechanism by which a probe with unvalued features seeks a matching goal within its c-command domain; replaces government-based feature checking in Minimalism.
The operation that moves a constituent already present in a syntactic object to a new position; the Minimalist reanalysis of classical transformational movement.
The research program mapping fine-grained functional projections in the left periphery, TP, and DP; associated with Rizzi's split-CP and related work.
The Linear Correspondence Axiom deriving universal base-generated Spec-Head-Comp order and accounting for cross-linguistic variation via movement; a foundational result in formal syntax.
A framework in which morphological operations apply post-syntactically to syntactic terminal nodes, eliminating a separate morphological component; widely used in expert-level morphosyntax research.
The Minimalist view that movement creates a copy at the tail of a chain, with the lower copy typically deleted at PF; replaces traces in earlier frameworks.
The mechanism whereby C and v pass their edge features to T and V respectively, enabling Agree without the phase head itself acting as probe; a refinement within phase theory.

A proposal allowing adjuncts to merge into a derivation after the containing constituent has been spelled out, circumventing certain island effects; a technical tool in current Minimalist derivations.
Chomsky's replacement for bar-level projections, determining the label of a syntactic object via feature sharing or head status; a cutting-edge topic in post-2013 Minimalism.

A movement strategy in which a constituent is evacuated from a larger phrase before that phrase moves, allowing what would otherwise be an island-violating extraction; an advanced analytical technique in contemporary syntax.
